primary: He was three years above me
example:
A: You know Dave?
B: Yeah, he was three years above me in high school.
A: Did you guys hang out?
B: Not really, since he was three years above me.
A: He seems older.
B: He is, he was three years above me in college.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は３（みっ）つ年上（としうえ）だった。／３（さん）学年（がくねん）先輩（せんぱい）だった。
chinese: 他是我高三届的学长 (tā shì wǒ gāo sān jiè de xuézhǎng)
spanish: Me sacaba tres años. / Iba tres cursos por delante de mí.

example:
A: Why didn't you answer?
B: I was booked solid all day.
A: Did you get a table?
B: No, the restaurant was booked solid.
A: You tired?
B: Exhausted, I was booked solid this week.
japanese: 予約（よやく）で満杯（まんぱい）だった。／全然（ぜんぜん）空（あ）いてなかった。
chinese: 我当时忙得不可开交 (wǒ dāngshí máng de bùkěkāijiāo)
spanish: Estaba totalmente ocupado. / Tenía todo completo.

example:
A: There's tension between them.
B: Did you pick up on that too?
A: He was lying.
B: Yeah, I picked up on that immediately.
A: Subtle shade intended.
B: I picked up on that.
japanese: 今（いま）のわかった？／気（き）づいた？
chinese: 你注意到了吗? (nǐ zhùyì dào le ma?)
spanish: ¿Te percataste de eso? / ¿Lo notaste?

example:
A: Should we get sushi or pizza?
B: Honestly, I'm starving so anything works. It's up to you.
A: Pizza might be faster.
B: Pizza it is then. Where should we order from?
A: Joe's? Or that new spot on 5th?
B: Your call. I trust your taste.
japanese: 任（まか）せるよ。／好（す）きにしていいよ。
chinese: 由你决定 (yóu nǐ juédìng) / 随便你 (suíbiàn nǐ)
spanish: Depende de ti. / Tú decides.

primary: Don't let it get to you
meaning: 마음에 담아두지 마. 신경 쓰지 마.
example:
A: He was so rude to me like that.
B: Don't let it get to you. He's just grumpy.
A: It just ruined my whole mood.
B: Don't give him that power. Let's go eat.
A: You're right. Forget him.
B: That's the spirit.
japanese: 気（き）にしないで。／真（ま）に受（う）けないで。
chinese: 喝醉了 (hē zuì le)
spanish: Borracho. / Pasado de copas.

meaning: 나를 위한 사치. 호강 좀 하다.
example:
A: You look relaxed.
B: I decided to pamper myself today.
A: Spa day?
B: Massage, facial, the works.
A: I'm jealous.
B: You should come next time.
japanese: 自分（じぶん）へのご褒美（ほうび）。／贅沢（ぜいたく）する。
chinese: 犒劳自己 (kàolao zìjǐ) / 享受一下 (xiǎngshòu yīxià)
spanish: Mimarme. / Darme un capricho.

example:
A: What are you doing?
B: Just sipping on some coffee. You?
A: Working hard.
B: Join me.
A: I wish.
B: I'll save you a cup.
japanese: コーヒーをちびちび飲（の）んでる。／コーヒーブレイク中（ちゅう）。
chinese: 品咖啡 (pǐn kāfēi) / 喝着咖啡 (hēzhe kāfēi)
spanish: Tomando un cafecito. / Disfrutando del café.

example:
A: How did you end up in Mexico?
B: One thing led to another.
A: Sounds wild.
B: It was a crazy night.
A: Tell me everything.
B: Maybe later.
japanese: いろいろあって。／成（な）り行（ゆ）きで。
chinese: 不知不觉就... (bùzhībùjué jiù...) / 事情就这样发生了 (shìqíng jiù zhèyàng fāshēng le)
spanish: Una cosa llevó a la otra. / Y así acabamos.

example:
A: I was right, wasn't I?
B: I hate to admit it, but yes.
A: Say it louder.
B: Don't push your luck.
A: I'll record it.
B: No.
japanese: 認（みと）めたくないけど。／癪（しゃく）だけど。
chinese: 我不想承认 (wǒ bùxiǎng chéngrèn) / 不得不承认 (bùdébù chéngrèn)
spanish: No tener pelos en la lengua. / Decir las cosas claras.

example:
A: Everyone hates cilantro.
B: I love it.
A: You're an outlier.
B: More for me.
A: True.
B: Enjoy your soap weed.
japanese: 変（か）わり種（だね）。／逸脱（いつだつ）してる。
chinese: 局外人 (júwàirén) / 异类 (yìlèi)
spanish: Caso atípico. / Excepción.

meaning: 너무 깊게 생각하지 마 (의미 부여 마)
similar: 3. Don't make a mountain out of a molehill
example:
A: He didn't text me back for three hours.
B: Don’t read into that much, he's busy.
A: You think he's losing interest in me?
B: Seriously, it's not that deep.
A: I keep checking my phone every minute.
B: Stop over-analyzing and just relax.
japanese: 要点（ようてん）はそこじゃない。／ズレてるよ。
chinese: 别想太多 (bié xiǎng tài duō) / 别过度解读 (bié guòdù jiědú)
spanish: No le des tanta importancia. / No busques segundas intenciones.

primary: scan and understand key points quickly
example:
A: Why did you use so many headers?
B: So the client can scan and understand key points quickly, deadass.
A: Smart move, they probably don't have time for a deep dive.
B: Facts, everyone in this city is always in a hurry.
A: No cap, but this makes it way easier for them.
B: That's the goal, no cap.
chinese: 一目了然 (yīmùliǎorán) / 快速抓重点 (kuàisù zhuā zhòngdiǎn)
spanish: Escanear y entender puntos clave rápido. / Leer en diagonal y pillar lo básico.

example:
A: Sorry I couldn't make it to your party.
B: No hard feelings, deadass. I know you were swamped with work.
A: Preciate that, man. I lowkey felt bad about it.
B: For real, don't even trip. We'll link up next week.
A: Say less, I'm down.
B: Bet.
japanese: 悪（わる）く思（おも）わないでね（恨（うら）みっこなしで）。
chinese: 别往心里去 (bié wǎng xīnlǐ qù) / 咱们还是朋友 (zánmen háishì péngyǒu)
spanish: Matar dos pájaros de un tiro. / Dos en uno.

example:
A: Hey, do you have a second for some gossip? 
B: Of course, I'm all ears. 
A: So, you won't believe what happened at lunch. 
B: Lay it on me, what's the tea? 
A: Sarah and the manager had a huge argument. 
B: No way! I'm listening, tell me more.
japanese: 興味津々（きょうみしんしん）で聞（き）く／注意深（ちゅういぶか）く聞（き）く
chinese: 洗耳恭听 (xǐ'ěrgōngtīng) / 愿闻其详 (yuànwénqíxiáng)
spanish: Te escucho. / Atento.

example:
A: Can I help you find anything specific today? 
B: No thanks, I'm just browsing. 
A: Feel free to ask if you need a different size. 
B: I appreciate it, I'm just window shopping for now. 
A: Our new collection is over in that corner. 
B: Thanks, I'll just keep looking around.
japanese: ただ見（み）ているだけです（店員に対して）
chinese: 我随便看看 (wǒ suíbiàn kànkan)
spanish: Solo estoy mirando. / Echando un vistazo.

example:
A: How did the meeting with the new client go?
B: Great! We really hit it off during lunch. 
A: That’s a relief; I heard they were difficult.
B: Not at all, we clicked instantly over shared hobbies.
A: I'm glad to hear you're seeing eye to eye.
B: Yeah, we got along famously from the start.
japanese: 意気投合（いきとうごう）する／馬（うま）が合（あ）う
chinese: 一见如故 (yījiànrúgù) / 很合得来 (hěn hédélái)
spanish: Congeniar. / Hacer buenas migas.

example:
A: We could order pizza for the party. 
B: Better yet, let's have a BBQ in the park! 
A: That sounds like even more fun. 
B: Alternatively, we could go to that new bistro. 
A: No, the BBQ is a great idea. 
B: Or, here's an idea: let's do both!
japanese: いっそのこと／もっといいのは
chinese: 甚至更好 (shènzhì gèng hǎo)
spanish: Nunca digas nunca. / Todo es posible.

example:
A: Um, I have something I need to tell you...
B: Just spit it out already! You're making me nervous.
A: I accidentally shrank your favorite sweater.
B: Oh... is that all? I thought it was something bad.
A: Are you mad? I feel terrible about it.
B: It's fine, it was getting old anyway.
japanese: はっきり言（い）えよ／白状（はくじょう）しろよ
chinese: 快说 (kuài shuō) / 吐出来 (tǔ chūlái)
spanish: Suéltalo ya. / Desembucha.

primary: That would be the best case scenario.
similar: If everything goes right, that's what happens.
example:
A: If we launch by Monday, we'll beat all our competitors.
B: That would be the best case scenario. Everyone's working overtime.
A: Do you think we can actually make it happen?
B: It's a tight squeeze, but it's definitely possible.
A: Fingers crossed. This would be huge for the team.
B: For real. Let's just keep this momentum going.
japanese: それが一番（いちばん）いい形（かたち）だね／理想（りそう）的（てき）だね
chinese: 那是最好的情况 (nà shì zuìhǎo de qíngkuàng)
spanish: Ese sería el mejor escenario. / Eso sería lo ideal.

similar: I'm with you all the way.
example:
A: I'm finally gonna ask for that promotion this afternoon.
B: Go for it! Honestly, I'm right behind you 100%.
A: Thanks. I'm still a little nervous about how they'll react.
B: You've earned it, so just be confident and state your case.
A: Your support really means a lot to me. Fingers crossed!
B: You'll kill it. Let's celebrate after work either way.
japanese: 応援（おうえん）してるよ。／バックアップするよ。
chinese: 我支持你 (wǒ zhīchí nǐ)
spanish: Te apoyo. / Cuento contigo.

example:
A: Do you think you can show me how to assemble this IKEA desk?
B: For sure! Look, there's nothing to it once you follow the pictures.
A: I'm just always terrified I'm gonna have extra screws at the end.
B: Haha, it happens to the best of us. Just take it slow and you'll be fine.
A: Alright, let's get down to business then.
B: Bet. Hand me that Allen wrench.
japanese: 簡単（かんたん）だよ。／どうってことないよ。
chinese: 没什么大不了的 (méishénme dàbùliǎo de) / 很简单 (hěn jiǎndān)
spanish: Más vale tarde. / Mejor tarde que nunca.

example:
A: Did you ask him about the missing files yet?
B: Yeah, but as soon as I mentioned the budget, he just clammed up.
A: That's suspicious. He's usually so talkative about everything else.
B: For real. It's like he's hiding something he doesn't want me to find.
A: I should probably have a more formal chat with him tomorrow.
B: Good luck with that. He's acting very strange lately.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は黙（だま）り込（こ）んじゃった。／貝（かい）になっちゃった。
chinese: 他一声不吭 (tā yīshēngbùkēng) / 闭口不言 (bìkǒubùyán)
spanish: A palabras necias, oídos sordos. / Ignora las tonterías.

primary: I'm a glass half full person.
similar: I try to look on the bright side.
I focus on the good things.
example:
A: Everything is going wrong today! This project is a absolute disaster.
B: Look, I'm a glass half full person. At least we found the problem early.
A: How can you be so positive right now? We're literally three days behind schedule!
B: Panicking won't help. Let's just focus on what we can fix today.
A: I guess you're right. Your attitude is actually kind of helpful, for real.
B: Facts. Let's just take it one step at a time and we'll get through it.
japanese: 楽観的（らっかんてき）なんだ。／物事（ものごと）を良（よ）い方（ほう）に捉（とら）えるタイプなんだ。
chinese: 我很乐观 (wǒ hěn lèguān)
spanish: Ser un aguafiestas. / Arruinar la diversión.

primary: He was as hard as nails.
similar: He was incredibly tough and unsympathetic.
He had a cold and unyielding personality.
He was very stern and strict.
He was emotionally distant and harsh.
He didn't show any mercy or weakness.
example:
A: I heard the old professor was absolute nightmare to work with.
B: Man, he was as hard as nails. He never gave anyone a break, no cap.
A: No matter how hard I studied, I could never get a grade higher than a B-.
B: For real. He used to fail people for the smallest mistakes. It was brutal.
A: Some people are just built differently, in a bad way.
B: Facts. I'm just glad I finally finished his class and moved on.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は冷徹（れいてつ）だったよ
chinese: 他铁石心肠 (tā tiěshíxīncháng)
spanish: Hacer leña del árbol caído. / Aprovecharse.

primary: I can feel it in my bones.
similar: I've got a really strong gut feeling.
I just know it's going to happen.
It's an undeniable feeling I have.
I'm certain of it deep down.
example:
A: Do you really think they're going to hire you?
B: Yes! I can feel it in my bones. The interview was perfect.
A: I hope you're right, you've been wanting this for ages.
B: I know, and everything just felt so right today.
A: When are they supposed to let you know?
B: By the end of the week. Keeping my fingers crossed!
japanese: 予感（よかん）がする／直感（ちょっかん）で分（わ）かる
chinese: 我直觉很准 (wǒ zhíjué hěn zhǔn) / 我有预感 (wǒ yǒu yùgǎn)
spanish: Hacer el ganso. / Hacer tonterías.

example:
A: Can I just add one more thing?
B: Sorry, time's up.
A: Just a second!
B: Rule is a rule, man.
A: Dang, I was so close.
B: Maybe next time.
japanese: 時間（じかん）切（ぎ）れ／そこまで
chinese: 时间到 (shíjiān dào)
spanish: Hacer guardia. / Vigilar.

primary: I'm afraid we're out of stock.
example:
A: Do you have these sneakers in size 10?
B: I'm afraid we're out of stock until next week.
A: Dang, I really wanted these.
B: Try the branch downtown, they might have 'em.
A: Good idea, thanks.
B: No prob.
japanese: 在庫（ざいこ）切（ぎ）れです／売（う）り切（き）れです
chinese: 恐怕没货了 (kǒngpà méihuò le)
spanish: Hacer pinitos. / Dar los primeros pasos.

primary: I can hold my head high.
example:
A: People are talking about your decision.
B: Let them talk, I can hold my head high.
A: You really think it was the right call?
B: 100%. I did the right thing, no cap.
A: Respect your integrity.
B: Thanks, it's what matters.
japanese: 胸（むね）を張（は）れるよ
chinese: 我问心无愧 (wǒ wènxīnwúkuì)
spanish: Hacer un balance. / Evaluar.

example:
A: I'm quitting my job to become a professional clown.
B: You can't be serious... tell me you're joking.
A: I'm 100% serious, I already got the shoes.
B: Man, you're wild. Good luck with the nose then.
A: Honk honk!
B: Oh boy.
japanese: 冗談（じょうだん）でしょ？／本気（ほんき）じゃないよね？
chinese: 你不是认真的吧 (nǐ bùshì rènzhēn de ba) / 别开玩笑了 (bié kāiwánxiào le)
spanish: Hacer un llamamiento. / Llamar la atención.

example:
A: They're gonna grill me in the meeting.
B: Don't worry, I got your back.
A: Thanks, I'm nervous.
B: We're a team.
A: I appreciate it.
B: Let's crush this.
japanese: 私がついてるよ／援護（えんご）するよ
chinese: 我挺你 (wǒ tǐng nǐ) / 有我呢 (yǒu wǒ ne)
spanish: Estar al tanto. / Estar informado.

example:
A: He quit smoking by sheer force of will.
B: That's tough, respect to him.
A: You need strong force of will to finish a marathon.
B: For real, my legs would give out at mile 2.
A: Her force of will is scary proficient.
B: She gets what she wants, period.
japanese: 意志（いし）の力（ちから）
chinese: 意志力 (yìzhìlì)
spanish: Dar guerra. / Causar problemas.

example:
A: Sorry, I think I bumped against your table.
B: It's cool, no water spilled.
A: The subway was so crowded, I bumped against like ten people.
B: Rush hour vibes, gotta love it.
A: I bumped against the wall in the dark.
B: Ouch, you okay?
japanese: ぶつかった
chinese: 撞到 (zhuàng dào)
spanish: Choqué contra. / Me golpeé con.

example:
A: You need to clean your room right now.
B: Why do I always have to do it? It's not even that messy.
A: Don't sass me, just get it done.
B: I'm just saying, it's unfair!
A: One more word and you're grounded.
B: Fine, I'm going.
japanese: 口答（くちごた）えしないで
chinese: 别跟我顶嘴 (bié gēn wǒ dǐngzuǐ)
spanish: No me contestes mal. / No seas irrespetuoso.
